>>89992337
>Plus measurements itself not reliable past 10kHz
Has mostly to do with coupler-tip cavity resonances. This isn't a reliability issue per se and has more to do with the lengthwise damping not being specified.
>Due to resonances in the acoustic transfer impedance of the occluded-ear simulator above 10 kHz, high measurement uncertainties, e.g. in the order of 10 dB, can occur in earphone responses. Repeatable results mainly are obtained for insert earphones with high acoustic damping
You can pin down this resonance by specifying the insert depth.

READ THE WIKI! & help by contributing:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server

>NAS Case Guide. Feel free to add to it:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server/Case_guide

/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. Know all about NAS? Learn virtualization. Spun up some VMs? Learn about networking by standing up a OPNsense/pfsense box and configuring some VLANs. There's always more to learn and chances to grow. Think you’re god-tier already? Setup OpenStack and report back.

>What software should I run?
Install Gentoo. Or whatever flavor of *nix is best for the job or most comfy for you. Jellyfin to replace Netflix, nextcloud to replace Googlel, ampache to replace spotify, the list goes on and on. Look at the awesome self-hosted list and ask.

>Why should I have a home server?
Learn something new. De-botnet your life. Serving applications to yourself, your family, and your frens feels good. Put your /g/ skills to good use for yourself and those close to you. Store their data with proper availability redundancy and backups and serve it back to them with a /comfy/ easy to use interface.

>>89992748
That is retarded on so many levels and this is coming from someone who has extensively looked into ATA Security and TCG Opal.

First of all there have been plenty (definitely more than Secure Boot) vulnerabilities with ATA Security. The problem here is that 1. you rely on the vendor's implementation of ATA Security and drive encryption (regardless whether it fits the TCG specs or not) and 2. you also rely on the BIOS or UEFI implementation. Believe it or not, some vendors actually store the password on your BIOS/UEFI, sometimes weakly hashed or even in cleartext. Crucial for example has proven to be incompetent as fuck because Crucial drives had a default master password on all their drives.

I use hardware encryption + secureboot (own keys) + LUKS/dmcrypt. Anyone who claims secureboot is "useless" is a retarded nigger. It is perfect? No. Does it prevent the vast majority of fucking with your bootloader? Yes. Apparently your pea brain can't into game theory.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89988660
Your average IPS looks way better than your average TN, ***for_a_static_image***, and that's what sells monitors. Most people don't even see the monitor they're about to buy in a store, let alone actually use one before buying. It's all on Amazon anymore. At best they'll read a review or look at a comparison image.

Like this>>89990243 anon says, there are solid reason to use a TN even now, and the native 8-bit panels are actually very, very good. They still have color inversion at angles, though.

When IPS was new, Asus made two high refresh monitors, one TN and other IPS. I was pumpped for the IPS, until I went into a store and played with both side by side. The TN was waaaay better, and not just in motion. It actually had better colors! The IPS was brighter, but the colors were very fucked up, like everything was neon and I couldn't get a good calibration. The motion was fucking awful but the worst was the backlighting, which bled so badly that it made the contrast of the TN look good.

TLDR try your monitor in person, and a few others, before dropping serious cash.

Tiger 10.4.11 is the last officially supported OSX version for your machine, so that's what I would install. Leopard CAN be installed on a G3, but it'll be slow as hell without Altivec, and with less than a gig of ram (640mb is the max for your machine) it'll probably border on unusable.

Other than that, like other people have said, the update servers for Jaguar and Tiger are offline, so your best bet is to just install 10.4.11 from the 4CD installer and use the version of iTunes that comes with that.
>>89992068
shit, didn't see this before I started replying. Yeah, a G3 is pretty useless except for a collector's piece. If you have any interest in PowerPC Macs (for like, getting offline DAW/photo editing work done, which they are still useful for), I would look into the following models:
- Powerbook G4 1.5ghz/1.67ghz (still not very fast but you can do basic internet browsing on them and fiddle around in logic and garageband)
- G4 MDD 1.25ghz dual (can throw Pro Tools MIX cards in them and have a really nice PT TDM 6.4.1 system, you can also throw a Delta 1010 or a MOTU PCI interface in there if you want something that'll play nice with Cubase/Nuendo/Digital Performer)
-G5 2.7ghz dual, early 2005 PCI-X model (can throw an RME HDSP card in there and run pretty massive Logic sessions, good luck finding one that doesn't have liquid damage from a failed LCS though)
-Late 2005 2ghz/2.3ghz Dual core/2.5ghz Quad G5 (probably the best tradeoff of speed and reliability, the one drawback is that it was the only Power Mac that had PCIe slots, and so not many OEMs put out PPC drivers for their PCIe interfaces. You can, however, put HD Accel cards in there and build a pretty beastly and dirt cheap Pro Tools HD3 Accel system). You can also convert the Quad to air cooled and circumvent all the LCS issues it had. Mine is pretty comfy

last_replies.com:
>>89992617
(2/2)

If you want to install Tiger via USB, you'll have to plug in your flash drive into the port closest to the firewire port, boot into OpenFirmware (CMD+Option+O+F) type in 
boot usb1/disk@1:3,\\:tbxi
and hit enter and it should take about 2 1/2 - 3 minutes to get to the language selection screen (depending on your USB drive's speed). The earliest version of Tiger that booted over USB for me was 10.4.6 (I've heard 10.4.4 works, but any earlier and you'll get the dreaded 'No' symbol). Another thing to keep in mind that the flash drive must be partitioned with the Apple Partition Map and imaged with the OS X install media using Disk Utility in order to boot. Lastly, this generation of iBook only has USB 1.1 so it's gonna take a good part of your day to install Tiger.
If you're feeling brave, you might wanna repurpose your iPod as a Firewire external drive and install Tiger from that. Never tried it myself, but I'd imagine it would definitely be faster than USB 1.1: https://www.engadget.com/2004-08-17-how-to-use-an-ipod-as-a-bootable-drive.html

GL, I've had fun tooling around with my iBook and I hope you enjoy yours as well.

Having fewer instructions and registers does not make a cpu easier to program. It makes it harder, because performing the simplest of tasks requires so many instructions, you have to continuously load values in and out of memory to do anything. This means having to keep track of zero page allocations. I don't comprehend how you think x86 is worse, x86 is on the upper end of programming ease, even the 8086 segments were not that bad as you could ignore them and still address 16bits of memory.

threads.sub: A secret linux cat easter egg
threads.com:
There is a secret easter egg where you can activate a virtual cat on a linux or a UNIX system. Though you should remember that it will only come up if it accepts you summoning it. If it does not agree on the other hand, your computer will be frozen and you will be forced to restart. Though the cat is not harmful enough to cause any tampering to your files or the system in any way. Make sure you save all your current, complete all copy or paste operations if running and close all the programs before you attempt to summon the cat.

To summon the cat, try the following command:


```
meow() { meow | meow & }; meow
```


If you see something like
```
[1] 583341
[1]+ Done meow|meow
```


Quickly up arrow and rerun the command untill you see no output. And after a few seconds the cat will appear(assuming it accepts you summoning it)

namespace your git clones by clone URL
(name this something like git-clone-ns)
url="$1"
shift
cd "${HOME:-'~'}/src"
case "$url" in
        (*'%'*)    exit 1 ;;             # Err if URL already contains any %s.
        (*'://'*)  dir="${url#*://}" ;;  # Strip protocol if there is one.
        (*)        dir="$url"            # Case for user@host type URLs.
esac
git clone "$url" "$dir" "$@"
